title: pm conservative party brexit james forsyth opinion
story: Despite her best efforts, May leaves behind no legacy.She’ll be remembered as the Prime Minister who, more than anything , failed to deliver Brexit.But the Tory party must learn from her failures.If it does not, then Jeremy Corbyn will be in Number  soon enough.May’s premiership was crippled by the  General Election. Her loss of the Tory majority robbed her of her authority, boxed her in on Brexit and discredited her domestic policy agenda.The failure of that campaign carries an important lesson for the Tories — they need a happy warrior.May looked deeply uncomfortable on the campaign trail, with the result that the more the public saw of her, the less they liked.This Tory need for a good campaigner is heightened by the fact that their next leader will have to fight on two fronts, against both Jeremy Corbyn and Nigel Farage.On Brexit, May’s biggest problem was not knowing what she wanted. She triggered Article , the two-year process for leaving the EU that we had to request a humiliating delay to, without a clear idea of the kind of relationship she wanted — and how to get it.This meant that the UK wasted valuable negotiating time and ceded the initiative to the EU in the talks.The Tories need a leader with a plan. Whoever succeeds May will have to know what they want to get out of the EU and how they plan to get it. Given Brussels’ intransigence in these talks, they are also going to need Plans B, C and D.One of May’s other failings was that she didn’t understand one of the key purposes of preparations for No Deal.It wasn’t because you actually wanted — or thought you would end up with — No Deal. It was meant to secure a better deal.The leadership contest, overseen by party chairman Brandon Lewis, will take around six weeks.Any Tory MP can enter the race, and the list of contenders is then whittled down by the parliamentary party.MPs vote in multiple rounds, eliminating one candidate each time until just two are left.The partys , activists then choose behind the final shortlist of two, with the winner declared leader and Prime Minister.When Mrs May became leader, she didnt have to submit to a vote of members because Andrea Leadsom pulled out of the race.So the last time activists have had a say on the leadership was , when David Cameron defeated David Davis.If the UK had been more visibly prepared to walk away, then the EU would have been more constructive in the negotiations.The new Prime Minister must spend the summer examining the state of our no-deal preparations.Absurdly, the Brexit delay has not been used as a chance to improve the UK’s no-deal planning but rather as an excuse to soft pedal. That must change.May’s other great failure has been failing to build a team or create a sense of collective endeavour.Both the disastrous  manesto and her Brexit plan were executed with far too little Cabinet involvement.She sent civil servants to do the very political job of negotiating. The result was a deal that was, unsurprisingly, politically tone deaf.May’s successor must appoint a Cabinet of all the Tory talents — and let them do their jobs.And we need a Brexit Secretary who actually negotiates with Brussels.The Tories have no perfect candidate for No . No one fully fulfils all of these requirements.But a Prime Minister who could deliver Brexit would give the Tories a fighting chance.THE way to think about the Tory leadership contest is that it is like a tournament with two sides of the draw, with each side sending one candidate into the final membership round.One side of the draw is for full-on Brexiteers.Here Boris Johnson, Dominic Raab, Andrea Leadsom, Steve Baker and Esther McVey will duke it out.The other side of the draw features the Cabinet candidates: Jeremy Hunt, Sajid Javid, Michael Gove, Matt Hancock and Rory Stewart.Whoever comes out of the Brexit side of the draw will go into the final round as the strong favourite, given how Tory members just want the UK to get out of the EU.I understand that Boris Johnson has edged ahead of Dominic Raab on this side of the contest.But he will, in the words of one key MP, need to be “materially ahead” of Raab on the first round.Why  Because Raab is more likely to pick up support as more hardline Brexiteer candidates such asRaab’s pitch will be that the Conservative Party is toastit cannot deliver Brexit – and that he is the man to do that.He will argue that other candidates might be better known than him, but Boris’s celebrity won’t save the Toriesthey cannot get Brexit done.But one of Boris’s advantages over Raab is that he has more reach into the rest of the party.His campaign is beginning to pick up support from former Remainer ministers, who see the former London Mayor as the Tories’ best chance of seeing off the twin threats of Corbyn and Farage.At the same time, some on the left of the party have decided that stopping Raab – who they see as a down-the-line right-winger – is now their priority, rather than blocking Boris.ON the Cabinet side of the contest, the question is whether Michael Gove can overhaul Jeremy Hunt.The Foreign Secretary currently has more MPs backing him than anyone  in the Cabinet.But his campaign has had a bumpy few weeks, and some of his supporters are beginning to peel away.This, perhaps, explains why Hunt felt the need to confirm that he was standing just hours after Theresa May announced her resignation yesterday.Part of Hunt’s problem with MPs is that it is very hard to see him beating Boris Johnson or Dominic Raab when it comes to the party members.Their experience with Theresa May has made the membership very wary of former Remainers.GEORGE Osborne has finally had his revenge on Theresa May.He sent a text to a slew of Cabinet leadership hopefuls saying that a big prize awaited the minister who went and told May that the Withdrawal Agreement Bill had to be pulled.Several recipients of this text were amused when Sajid Javid, who was one of Osborne’s junior ministers at the Treasury, then went to demand that May shelve the second referendum part of the bill.SOME members of the  parliamentary intake are considering running for the leadership.They should hold their horses – the new leader will need more than four years of parliamentary experience.But whoever becomes the new PM needs to freshen up the Cabinet, to bring in this new talent.After nine years in government, there are too many administrators in Cabinet and not enough doers.It needs an injection of energy and fresh ideas.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may finally shows emotion too late
story: She’d announced her resignation, laid out her achievements in office and was in the closing seconds of telling the nation she felt no ill will now her premiership is at an end.Then the chin started to wobble, the voice cracked and, as she emotionally emphasised the words “the country I love”, her real feelings emerged.Only the hardest of hearts could fail to feel sorry for her particularly as, unlike other Prime Ministers in the past, she chose to stand outside Downing Street alone.There was pain in that last sentence, a deep-seated fondness for Britain, and an over-whelming sense that she clearly feels a burning sense of injustice at how she’s perceived by her many detractors — myself among them.But no one has ever questioned Mrs May’s sense of duty to her country.In fact, as many of her political colleagues flocked to lavish post-resignation praise, the recurring theme was that of “dedicated public servant”.Admirable, yes, and probably makes you a “strong and stable” MP for Maidenhead.But when it comes to leading the country, that elusive “X Factor” is needed.In fact,she had shown just one small flash of that “country I love” passion in her dealings with the EU she might have successfully delivered Brexit and stayed in the top job for many more years.Instead, she became known as the “Maybot” thanks to her robotic delivery of speeches and failure to communicate effectively with the electorate and even her own cabinet colleagues.It’s a shame, because women in particular will know the sacrices she has made in becoming only the second female Prime Minister in an arena still dominated by machismo.But in the end, it wasn’t enough.You need imagination and breadth of vision to lead the country through Brexit and sadly Ms May had neither.So yes, I’m sorry to see her obvious distress.But I’m not sorry to see her go. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may apology staff resignation
story: The Prime Minister had reportedly been annoyed by previous “sexist and inaccurate” claims she wept during recent cabinet meetings about her future.But when she broke down in front of nation while declaring her intention to quit, after failing to lead the UK out of the EU, she apologised to her aides, the Daily Mail reports.The beleaguered PM was met with applause when she came through the famous black door of Number , the reports says.One of her staff members told her: “Its not you who should be apologising, Prime Minister,” it has been claimed.Her allies within the government are reportedly furious with the way Brexiteers within the party have conspired to force her out.One source said: “I hope the people who had a hand in it are feeling guilty. They have made a huge miscalculation.”Mrs May, who became PM in the aftermath of the historic referendum result in , paid tribute to her husband Philip and her chief-of-staff Gavin Barwell.While telling aides how much the job had meant to her, members of her team began to shed tears.One staffer said: “It was a bit emotional but it was a nice moment.”The PM was forced to resign after she failed to deliver Brexit and lost the support of her own MPs - but will continue in office as a lame duck until July.Shortly after meeting Tory executioner Sir Graham Brady, she addressed the nation in the spring sunshine of Downing Street - watched by her adoring husband - and admitted her time is up.The PM confessed she now has no chance of ever getting her Brexit deal through Parliament but insisted I have done my best to deliver on the referendum result.She said: Ever since I first stepped through the door behind me as Prime Minister, I have striven to make the United Kingdom a country that works not just for a privileged few, but for everyone. And to honour the result of the EU referendum.If you give people a choice you have a duty to implement what they decide. I have done my best to do that.Sadly I have not been able to do so. I tried three times - I believe it was right to persevere even when the odds against success seemed high.Her voice cracking, she attempted to defend her legacy and insisted she has helped to fix Britains burning injustices.Mrs May concluded: I will shortly leave the job it has been the honour of my le to hold - the second female Prime Minister, but certainly not the last.I do so with no ill will but with enormous and enduring gratitude to have had the opportunity to serve the country I love.After her speech, the PM and Philip May drove off to spend the Bank Holiday weekend at their home in Sonning, Berkshire.

title: sun says theresa may best wasnt nearly enough
story: For all that her critics have thrown at her, The Sun included, who could fail to recognise the monstrous strain she has endured for three years Or her overwhelming sorrow at giving up the job she has wanted her whole le, with so little to show for it This PM will be remembered now for her failure to deliver Brexit. It will be ungenerous not to remember too her unshakeable dedication to her country and remarkable perseverance against what became insurmountable odds.She is a good person. She did her best.But she is a poor Prime Minister and the author of her own downfall. She appointed a Cabinet of loyal friends largely devoid of talent.She credulously swallowed bad advice from a staunchly europhile and dysal civil service.She lacked vital traits for a leader: core beliefs, confidence, decisiveness, mental agility, communication skills and a willingness to trust and delegate.These failings, and a suicidal manesto, were exposed at the  election. Stripped of her majority, she foolishly tried to pretend “nothing has changed” and made promises she couldn’t keep.She negotiated a Brexit deal which was bad enough even before Monday’s final, fatal compromises.Mrs May described what she sees as her legacy. It is thin gruel. The economy is doing fine, the job market booming. But she did next to nothing for Sun readers, for the “just about managings”.Brexit is undone, like her “social justice” agenda. Our democracy is in disarray, Britain ided, her party at historic poll lows. She leaves her successor an even more colossal task than her own.Whoever that is must, above all, stop Corbyn’s thuggish extremists winning power.That can only be done by delivering Brexit — yes, with No Dealneed be — and somehow seeing off the Brexit Party whose surge could let Corbyn in.Winning the battle of ideas against the Marxist Left will be far simpler. Who is best placed to do it It must be a Brexiteer ready to appoint a younger, fresher, far more talented top team. There are plenty of able Tories in the ranks, their paths blocked by ­Cabinet duds who must be swept away.Leave-backing MPs must avoid splitting their vote and letting another Remainer into No. The party may not survive it.Nor, we believe, will its members tolerate any attempt by MPs to block their favourite candidates. They now have Nigel Farage’s party to join.Mrs May has left the Tories in dire straits and with one chance to survive.For their sake — and Britain’s — they had better make the right choice.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: doctors boozing culture peer pressure
story: Nearly nine in ten complain of an embedded workplace boozing culture.It puts them top of a poll’s table, ahead of railway workers and IT staff.Professionals such as bankers, scientists, pharmacists and accountants also feature in the top ten.Ruari Fairbairns, of One Year, No Beer, said: “It’s shocking that doctors, managers and workers in big business feel immense pressure to drink.”The survey of , people also shows that a third feel they will be disadvantaged at workthey do not go out boozing with colleagues.More than four in ten say they deliberately dodge after-work bashes to avoid the boozing culture.A similar proportion say they are coerced into attending, despite insisting they are off alcohol.And seven in ten say they are made to feel awkward by colleaguesthey do not drink.The pressures to join in are felt more acutely by those aged  to  than their older workmates.Mr Fairbairns, whose company runs a no-drinking challenge, said feeling under pressure to drink makes it more dficult to give up.But he added: “When you overcome these obstacles it builds self-worth and that’s far more gratying than having a drink.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british steel mps demand official
story: NewsBritish Steel: MPs demand official inquiry into why firm went into liquidationEXCLUSIVE: Call for Greybull to be grilled in Parliament as to why , jobs were put at risk when company it had owned sold for £ShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAY NewsCalls for an inquiry into how British Steel was put into receivership, jeopardising , jobs, have grown louder "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCalls have flooded in for MPs to launch a probe after British Steel was plunged into liquidation. Parent firm Greybull Capital could be grilled in Parliament to explain how the company ended up on the brink. Unions, MPs and campaigners backed demands for the Commons ­Business Select Committee to open an inquiry into how the firm was put into receivership, jeopardising , jobs. Unite assistant general secretary Steve Turner called Greybull “bandits” and “the ugly face of capitalism”. He added: “They should never have been able to get their hands on one of this nation’s strategic industries.” The ­investment outfit bought British Steel for a £ in .    Mr Turner added: “Unite is determined they will be exposed for what they are, which is why we are pressing for a parliamentary inquiry and an end to the short-term profiteering that wrecks lives and the economy.” Community steelworkers’ union operations director Alasdair ­McDiarmid said: “The events are still unclear... MPs have a duty to get the facts out in the open.” Among the jobs at risk are , at British Steel’s Scunthorpe plant and , in the supply chain, after Greybull failed to secure a £million bailout loan from the Government. The firm was placed in receivership on Wednesday.   British Steel, which has blamed Brexit uncertainty for its troubles, had already been handed a £million loan to pay an EU emissions bill.Business Select Committee chairwoman Rachel Reeves signalled this week that MPs could demand evidence from Greybull. She said the committee “will want to look at what triggered the collapse”. Shadow Steel Minister Gill Furniss said: “There are many questions surrounding the management and finance of the company over the last three years and the workers in Scunthorpe, Teesside and North ­Yorkshire deserve answers.”   Labour MP Anna Turley, who is secretary of Parliament’s cross-party group on steel, fuelled hopes bosses would be called.She said: “Whilst our priority is securing a future for British Steel, we need answers.” aposBosses will slip away into the sunsetaposComment by Steve Turner, United Union Assistant General SecretaryYou would have to have a heart of stone not to feel for British Steel workers right now. Around , jobs at risk, families devastated and, until this week, without even a short-term guarantee of wages or work. A proud workforce has given their all to keep this industry alive, fighting against economic headwinds as well as the indference of successive governments. This is in sharp contrast to the two super-wealthy families who bankroll Greybull, the private financiers who bought the company for £ in . They’ll be slipping off into the sunset following the near collapse of a great company. British Steel must have a secure future, with a world class workforce producing a world class product.    aposWe walked into a furnace aloneaposComment by Marc Meyohas, Co-founder of Greybull CapitalBritish Steel was close to meltdown when Greybull took control. The plant was earmarked for closure and when everyone  was feeling the heat and deserting it, we were the only ones prepared to walk towards the furnace. We revived the British Steel name and had clear ambitions tothe business to its rightful place. Far from just paying £, we rallied a consortium of lenders and investors to pump in £million, including tens of millions of Greybull’s capital. And it was working. The business made a profit in , before being blown off course by a series of events, particularly Brexit. Everyone at Greybull is deeply saddened, but we would welcome an inquiry so lessons can be learned. We have nothing to hide. Tell us what you think: yourvoice@mirror

title: jeremy corbyn leads calls general
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn leads calls for general election so Brits can pick their next PMEXCLUSIVE: Labour leader has piled pressure on whoever replaces Theresa May to go to the public earlyShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAY NewsLabour leader Jeremy Corbyn has called for a general election in the wake of Theresa Mays resignation "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Corbyn stepped up calls for a general election last night as Theresa May prepared to skulk out of No for good. The Labour leader demanded the new Prime Minister seek their own mandate when they enter Downing Street by triggering what would be the third such poll in four years.David Cameron won a slender Conservative majority in  but Mrs May squandered it  months later in her disastrous snap election. The next general election is not due until . Mr Corbyn welcomed Mrs May’s decision to quit and piled pressure on whoever replaces her to go to the public early. Writing in the Mirror he said: “Britain doesn’t need a new Tory PM, we need a general election to elect a Labour Government on the side of the many, not the few.  “When a UN report reveals there are  million people in Britain living in poverty, when , children are living in insecure accommodation, then I think we’ve got to see the need for a real change of direction.” Labour could call a no-confidence vote with the aim of forcing a general election, but it would not get backing from Tories now Mrs May has announced she is stepping down.A Survation poll on voting intension this week had Labour out in front on %, the Conservatives %, the Lib Dems on %, the Brexit Party on %, the Greens on %, UKIP on % and Change UK on %.Based on that, Labour could take anything from around  to about  seats in a general election, depending on how votes broke down.  Labour got % of the popular vote in  but just  seats, while the Tories won .% and  seats.    If Labour got a third of votes and Tory support collapsed, as the poll suggests, Labour would most likely be the biggest party in a hung Parliament. Should a new Tory PM decide to call a snap poll, it is likely they would secure the backing of the two-thirds of MPs required under the Fixed Term Parliaments Act. However, one of the frontrunners to succeed Mrs May in No, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, last month warned it “would be absolutely catastrophic for us to face the people again in a general election”. Other Conservative leadership candidates are also likely to come under pressure to rule out triggering a fresh poll because a general election would hammer party finances, make new demands on loyal activists and risk opening the door to Labour. When Mrs May campaigned to become Tory leader in , she repeatedly ruled out a snap election – and then called one nine months after entering Downing Street. Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon yesterday backed calls for the new Prime Minister to seek a mandate from the public.  She said: “[Mrs May’s] departure will not solve the Brexit mess that the Tories have created. Only putting the matter back to the people can do that. “Given current circumstances, it also feels deeply wrong for another Tory to be installed in No without a general election.”Labour could turn to her Scottish National Party as a coalition partner or a confidence-and-supply deala general election resulted in a hung parliament, but the SNP would want a second independence referendum, which Labour opposes in Scotland.Dr Simon Usherwood, a reader in politics at the University of Surrey, pointed out that while the Tories could change their leader, they were unable to change the numbers in Parliament without a general election. He said: “When you get a party changing leaders and Prime Minister, there’s always a lot of pressure to have a general election because that’s not who people voted for. “There maybe a feeling in No from the new team that they may want to get a more explicit mandate than just one from their party. Certainly it’s going to be in the air. “The advantage of an election isyou’re someone who feels confident you’ve made a good initial impression, you’re catching the opposition on the hop and you improve your situation. “One of the problems May faced was she lacked a majority for the Conservatives. If a new leader came in and thought they had a good chance of getting back to where they were before , that would count for a lot. “It would not only mean they wouldn’t have to worry about [obtaining backing from] the DUP, it would also mean they were a winner in the eyes of MPs who might then be more willing to go along with whatever plan the new PM came up with.”    Dr Usherwood said the earliest a snap poll could take place is October. “You want a bit of time to bed down and make an impression, and also get a feel about whether you’re likely to be successful,” he added. “If you’re not doing it quickly, you’re probably just saying, ‘Let’s just hang on for the rest of term we have got until ’.” The GMB union also demanded the next PM call a new ballot. General secretary Tim Roache said: “Working people are sick of the Tories focusing on who is going to take Theresa May’s job when thousands across the country are losing theirs. “We cannot let Britain’s workers, industries and communities become the casualties of the next round of Tory internal wars. “Let’s have a general election and let the people decide.”    Public wail of grief from this private womanSketch by Ben Glaze, Deputy Political EditorAt .am on Friday, Mrs May emerged from No  and strode confidently to the government-crested lectern. Armed police guarded both ends of the street as two union flags fluttered in the cloudless spring sky. And, in a bizarre coincidence, in the security hut, offi­cers were doing a whip-round for a leaving colleague. Back at the lectern the PM reeled off what she believes were her greatest successes. But she also conceded she had failed to deliver Brexit. Occasionally lting her glance to the barrage of lenses pointed at her face, her speech didn’t falter. ut as her seven-minute address neared its end and she spoke of being the second woman PM, her voice began to give as she blinked back tears. And as she expressed her gratitude at serving “the country I love”, her voice collapsed to a wail. It was a deeply uncomfortable public show of emotion from this most private of women. Husband Philip, hands behind back, must have been in knots watching his we implode. How dferent from  when he beamed as she told of her ambition to confront “burning injustices”. In a grotesque reminder of the issue that haunted and has now doomed her premiership, as the PM turned and walked back towards the black door a lone protester shouted: “Stop Brexit!” QAWhat happens now Theresa May will cease to be Tory leader on Friday, June , but she will stay on as caretaker PM while a new party boss is elected. Conservative MPs will st through candidates in a series of votes until only two remain. The final pair will take part in hustings across the country, which will be open to non-members. But only Conservative members, numbering about ,, will have a say. Once a winner is announced, Mrs May will visit the Queen at Buckingham Palace, formally resign as PM and recommend the monarch appoints the victor. Moments later, her successor will become our new PM.What does this mean for Brexit The UK is due to leave the EU on October  with or without a deal. Bookies’ favourite Boris Johnson yesterday signalled his support for quitting without a pact. But MPs would surely try to find a way to stop a no-deal departure. A new PM could ask Brussels to look again at its Withdrawal Agreement offer. The EU has stressed it will not reopen the deal, but parliamentary deadlock, political chaos and a change in No throws everything up in the air.A further Brexit extension beyond Halloween could be requested. EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker leaves office in November, followed by European Council President Donald Tusk in December, potentially paving the way for a new deal to be negotiated – one which might get through the Commons. Will there be a second referendum Campaigners believe the ongoing turmoil boosts their cause for another vote. They claim once all other plans fail, there will be nowhere  to turn and a fresh poll will be the last option. But there is no majority in Parliament for a second referendum.Will there be a general election  Jeremy Corbyn wants one, but the polls are so volatile –– especially given the Brexit Party’s sudden rise – it is impossible to predict who would win.A new PM will study polls in minute detail to see whether it is worth them risking an election to secure their own mandate. The next No incumbent will be under huge pressure to boost their authority with an election. But all Tories will be wary of going to the country after Theresa May squandered the party’s majority with her disastrous snap poll in  after being unable to resist the lure of a -point poll lead.

title: next conservative leader odds runners
story: NewsNext Tory leader odds: Who will replace Theresa May as Prime Minister of the UK The Conservative leadership contest is fast resembling the Grand National with more than  MPs vying to replace Theresa May - who will step down on  JuneShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political EditorNicola BartlettOliver Milne:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video who-could-replace-theresa-tory-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has announced that she will step down as Tory leader on  June, meaning that the UK will have a new Prime Minister. More than  MPs have already mulled chucking their hats in the ring to replace her. And four have confirmed they plan to stand in the contest. Boris Johnson revealed he would be standing during a QA at the British Insurer’s Conference in Manchester. Askedhe would stand in the race, he said: “of course”. Former Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey was one of the first out of the gate, confirming her intention to stand in early May. She said: “I have always said quite clearlyI got enough support from my colleagues, yes I would. “Now people have come forward and I have got that support, so I will be going forward.” International Development Secretary Rory Stewart confirmed he planned to run in the contest earlier the same week, saying he could “bring the country together.” And within hours of Mrs May stepping down, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt told his local newspaper he would be running in the election. Unlike Mrs Mayaposs election in , where Tory members never voted, this race promises to be the most bruising in years. And just like her election, it will have profound consequences for Brexit - with a hard-right, Hard Leaver likely to take the reins. Possible candidates have been shamelessly jostling for position, holding secretive dinners, parading their families and doing puffy newspaper interviews in a bid to scoop up support. Some have even declared openly, with Boris Johnson booming: Iaposm going to go for it!  Under the rules of a Tory leadership race, candidates bidding for the crown must be nominated by two or more fellow Tory MPs. A series of knockout ballots is then held among MPs to whittle down the wide field of candidates to just two.  Those two preferred candidates go to a run-off of the wider Conservative Party, with its , members eligible to vote. The candidate who wins the most votes becomes the leader.  So, as the formal leadership contest begins, who are the people lining up to try and be your next Prime Minister  Weaposve looked at all the runners and riders, the frontrunnersapos odds and how much of a True Blue Tory Warrior™ they are.    All the Tory leadership contenders Declared openly that they want to runBoris Johnson Esther McVey Rory Stewart Jeremy HuntReported, hinted - or refused to rule outAndrea Leadsom Amber Rudd Matt Hancock Michael Gove Dominic RaabJames Cleverly Kit Malthouse Sajid Javid Penny Mordaunt Liz Truss Mark Harper David Gauke James Brokenshire Steve Baker Graham Brady Johnny Mercer Justine Greening Tom TugendhatThose who say they definitely WONaposT be runningDavid Lidington Jacob Rees-Mogg Tobias Ellwood David Davis Victoria Atkins Ken Clarke Dominic GrieveThe bookiesapos frontrunners Odds retrieved from Paddy Power, th May  Boris Johnson ODDS:  VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    Brexiteer and former foreign secretary Mr Johnson, , has been a leading voice against Theresa Mayaposs Brexit plan - and heaposs been preparing for this for years. The Old Etonian was one of the key players in the  Leave campaign after a last-minute decision to back Brexit. He resigned from the Cabinet in  in protest at Mayaposs plan. He was tipped as a successor to David Cameron but ruled himself out after Michael Gove stabbed him in the back with a last-minute bid for the top job. Since then heaposs lost weight and had a haircut in what many argued was a pre-leadership bid upgrade. Sure enough he confirmed by telling a business conference: Iaposm going to go for it! Selecting the former mayor of London for eight years would enrage Tory Remainers, who believe he is in this game only for himself and his ego. He became notorious for his attention-grabbing offensive comments, when he called black people piccaninnies, said Barack Obama was part-Kenyan and compared the EU to Adolf Hitler. Heaposs also criticised for vast sums of money he rakes in alongside being an MP for speeches and a £,-a-yearcolumn - which was rapped for inaccuracy by the press regulator. Meanwhile, heaposs been rapped for showing a lack of respect to Parliament by repeatedly breaking Commons rules. Supporters say that since splitting with his long-suffering we Marina Wheeler and shacking up with ex-Tory head of press Carrie Symonds, heaposs mended his ways and become more serious. But scores of Tory MPs would vote for Anyone But Boris and a Scottish operation to stop him was nicknamed Operation Arse. Dominic Raab ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING: .   During his four-month stint as Brexit Secretary, ultra-hard Leaver Dominic Raab suggested he would use leaving the EU to slash business taxes. Now heaposs running for leader heaposs hinted p could be slashed off income tax - cutting billions from the public purse. And that wasnapost all that would anger left-wingers. The -year-old sparked fury in  by saying most food bank users are not languishing in poverty. He claimed: The typical user... is someone who has a cash flow problem. When a disability activist told him people are dying under Tory austerity, he described her calls for cash as a childish wish list. And he put out a pamphlet in  that suggested exempting small firms from minimum wage laws for workers under . Mr Raab positioned himself early on for the leadership, setting out his plans to tackle kne crime with “robust policing” and community work. He also paraded in his home in a cringeworthy interview with his we. And he attempted to outflank hostile competition by addressing claims he used a gagging order, to silence a former colleague who accused him of bullying. Mr Raab told The Sunday Times the claims, which date back to  before he was an MP, were completely ”. Michael Gove ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Environment Secretary had a bruising experience in the last Tory leadership race stabbing Boris in the back before finishing third. And he kept his powder dry in the days immediately following Theresa Mayaposs announcement she would quit. But behind the scenes his allies, including Treasury minister Mel Stride, have been approaching MPs in the most unlikely positions to seethey will join his slate. One former Cabinet minister told the Mirror Mr Gove was one of the most likely to be elected. Despite infuriating teachers when he was Education Secretary, and stabbing Boris Johnson in the back for leadership in , the -year-old is seen as a competent media performer and has won plaudits as a campaigner for environmental issues. He has already paraded with his Scottish parents as part of the proxy leadership contest in the party. He was a prominent face in the Brexit campaign, but he isnapost wildly trusted by other figures on the Conservativesapos eurosceptic wing.    Jeremy Hunt ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt was a prominent Remainer in the  referendum. And now heaposs even more prominent - loudly positioning himself as a possible leadership contender. Heaposs taken select journalists on a high-profile trip to Africa and appeared in cringeworthily staged photos with his we. Later he made the leadership bid even more obvious by pointedly calling for more defence spending - a sure-fire hit with the Tory grassroots. As Health Secretary, Mr Hunt, , fought a long battle with the medical profession over a new contract for doctorsapos working conditions. The -year-old became Foreign Secretary in July following the resignation of Boris Johnson. He chose not to run in the  leadership contest and instead gave his full support to Mrs May, saying it was not the right time to put his hat in the ring. Mr Hunt made a public sht towards Euroscepticism after the referendum.    Andrea Leadsom ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old, grammar-school educated former bank executive is about as true blue Tory as you can get. She survived to the final two of the  Tory leadership race, pitching herself as the Hard Brexit, blue alternative to Theresa May with a cringeworthy march in Westminster. But she infamously pulled out after making controversial remarks about motherhood and trying to deny them. She has said she is seriously considering running for the leadership again. And she played a crucial part in forcing Theresa Mayaposs resignation announcement, after resigning from the PMaposs cabinet and blasting her Brexit plan just hours before the EU elections.    Penny Mordaunt ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    Recently promoted to Defence Secretary, Penny Mordaunt is a -year-old Royal Navy reservist whoaposs only been an MP since  - but has a rich slew of headlines to her name. From bellyflopping on TV ing show Splash! to slashing billions off benefits and lying about Brexit, sheaposs often been famous - and only sometimes for the right reasons. The daughter of a paratrooper and special needs teacher, who has a twin brother, the Portsmouth North MP went to her local comprehensive. She worked in a factory and as a magicianaposs assistant to save up for Reading University, which she was the first member of her family to go to. The PR supremo was director of communications for the National Lottery, head of campaigns for Diabetes UK, head of foreign press for George W Bush’s  and  election campaigns and chief of staff for former MP David Willetts.    Rory Stewart ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Hong Kong-born son of a diplomat, an Old Etonian, once admitted his career gives the appearance he was a spy. The -year-old delivered his own child after a career as a diplomat in the Foreign Office. He was elected MP for Penrith and the Border in  and joined the government in . The International Development Secretary wasted absolutely no time after being promoted to the Cabinet in May . He announced his pitch to be PM within hours. Mr Stewart said: I think itaposs important at this time when the Prime Ministeraposs said sheaposs going to step down to have a voice thataposs arguing for being radical. But, radical in the centre of British politics, not radical on the extreme right of British politics. Yet his approach - blindly following the PMaposs Brexit deal and saying it might even be worth splitting the party for - has made him wildly unpopular among Tory Brexiteers.    Sajid Javid  ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The Home Secretary has spent a few months warming up for a leadership bid. It’s widely expected the next Tory leader will be a Brexiteer. Meaning Mr Javid, , who backed Reman but now supports Leave, would have a real fight on his hands to win round Tory members. He took over at the Home Office after Amber Rudd was forced to quit over the Windrush scandal - and has picked public fights with Mrs May on key issues like immigration and police funding. But his star has fallen over chaotic handling of migrants crossing the Channel. He was accused of stoking tensions by declaring a national emergency to deal with a few hundred migrant crossings over a period of months. Mr Javid, the son of Pakistani bus driver, would be the first non-white Prime Minister. Matt Hancock ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING: .     The ambitious -year-old entered politics as George Osborneaposs adviser and was in the inner circle of the famously cliquey ex-Chancellor. The parkour- and karaoke-loving Conservative entered Parliament in , Government in  and joined the DCMS in July  after Mrs May took over as Prime Minister. He was swtly promoted to Culture Secretary and then Health Secretary. But he came under fire for accepting thousands from the boss of a think tank which wants to scrap the NHS. Within days of the PMaposs announcement, he somehow found his way onto the Good Morning Britain sofa, where he said of leadership: I think you don’t rule out these things.” Then, all but confirming he would run, he posed with a horse. Graham Brady ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old, made a Sir in , holds Theresa Mayaposs fate in his hands as chairman of the  Committee. The august body runs leadership challenges in the Conservative Party and could change the rules to force Mrs May out. Heaposs currently its premier diplomat in the Tory war, but could reportedly sacrice his immunity to run for the top job himself. The grammar-school-educated MP for Altrincham and Sale West is a former PR man who turned MP in  and was the chief aide to former Tory leader Michael Howard. James Cleverly ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:    The -year-old Brexiteer is a tub-thumping Tory whoaposs not afraid to go into battle on social media. The MP for Braintree has repeatedly got into spats with Labour since taking his job as Tory Vice Chair. Heaposs a boisterous character at social events and in the bars of Parliament, making up for a lack of Westminster experiencewith fierce public loyalty. Esther McVey  ODDS:   VOTED: Leave TRUE BLUE RATING:   The hardline Brexiteer confirmed she will be running for the Tory leadership with a pledge to slash £billion from foreign aid, and spend it on schools and the police. The former welfare-slasher and rank outsider said: Iaposve always said quite clearlyI got enough support from colleagues then yes I would, and now people have come forward and I have got that support. But former GMTV presenter Ms McVey became notorious among benefit claimants after working as a Minister and later Secretary of State in the Department for Work and Pensions. Her blunt style drew floods of criticism even when she managed to secure limited extra money for cash-starved Universal Credit, and U-turned on a benefit cut for the disabled.  Over the years, she made a number of controversial comments which turned her into a lightning rod for anger about benefits. She was ousted from her Wirral West seat in  after a sustained campaign against her, but ed in George Osborneaposs ultra-safe Tatton seat in . The -year-old has risen to prominence with stinging criticisms of the government from his  as chairman of the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee. He could be a figure to unite Remainers and softer Leavers in his warring party - especially the younger flock. But heaposs also an outside chance, and talk has focused more on him teaming up with a bigger beast on a joint ticket. David Gauke  ODDS:   VOTED: Remain TRUE BLUE RATING:    The pro-Remain Justice Secretary is highly unlikely to be putting his hat in the ring. But there is some suggested he could team up with fellow Remainer Amber Rudd to run on a joint ticket. He also gave a wide-ranging speech on Thursday  May straying beyond the confines of his brief. Mr Gauke took a swipe at populists like Boris Johnson saying: Populism would undermine the United Kingdom.  In the context of the United Kingdom, right-wing populism means English nationalism. title: pippa crerar not first last
story: NewsopinionPippa Crerar: May is not the first, or last, Tory to fall thanks to the EUMays successor will inherit the whole unresolved Brexit mess which also felled Cameron three years ago, writes Pippa CrerarShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY NewsopinionIts no surprise that Theresa May ended up resigning after the mess of Brexit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Theresa May contemplates her fate this weekend it will give her scant comfort to know she is not the first Tory leader to have been destroyed by Europe. David Cameron, John Major and Margaret Thatcher before her all suffered the same fate, as the Tory party’s obsession with Brussels picked them off one by one. Mr Cameron, at least, told his party to “stop banging on about Europe”, but then unleashed a referendum he was sure his own side would win. Her successor will inherit the whole unresolved Brexit mess.    Much as Boris Johnson or Jeremy Hunt, or whoever ends up as PM, may like to think they have the negotiating skills May lacked, they don’t. Skip forward a few months and they will realise that all the constraints faced by Mrs May exist for them too. But expectations, and frustrations, will have grown. As Mrs May has learned: uneasy lies the head that wears a crown.

News of the bash to celebrate to­­­morrow’s Grand Prix emerged after parent company Arcadia admitted the tycoon had not been near its London HQ “for nearly a year”. The bizarre claim came following new allegations Green, , had slap­­ped women workers’ bottoms. Rents at  other stores will be cut and all  Topman and Top­­shop outlets in the US are set to close. The pensions regulator does not believe the move will “ade­­quately protect” workers pen­­sions and ­yes­­terday Labour MP Frank Field called on Sir Philip to use his own cash to pay them out.Mr Field, who heads the Work and Pension Committee, told The Mirror: “Clearly he hasn’t got time for his business but he has time for a lavish party on a lavish yacht.    “He ought to make a lavish contribution to make up the mega pension deficit.” Shopworkers union Usdaw called Green’s skiving “unacceptable”. Arcadia said the firm was thor­­­oughly investigating all grievances.    Beast has deserted his crumbling lairComment by Graham HiscottPhilip Green once used his London office as a lair to lord it over the family fashion empire. With his company at risk of crumbling and yet more lurid allegations against him, Green is breaking the habit of a letime and keeping a low profile. Visits to the UK are rare and those to his HQ clearly rarer. Tory wannabe leader Rory Stewart has said he’d take Green’s knighthood away “tomorrow”. But it’s two and a half years since MPs voted that he didn’t deserve the gong. story: NewsSir Vince Cable launches Lib Dem leadership contest and confirms date hell quitThe contest will run almost exactly alongside the Tory leadership contestShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Sir Vince Cable has confirmed the date heaposll step down as leader of the Liberal Democrats , kicking off the race to replace him.He said in March that he would leave after the local elections, which took place earlier this month. title: theresa weeps during resignation speech
story: NewsTories scramble to replace Crying Lady Theresa May after teary resignationEmotional exit address saw May vow to quit as Tory leader on June , after Trumps visit, to make way for a new PM by the end of JulyShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsTheresa May broke down in bitter tears during her resignation speech today "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email First the Iron Lady, now the Crying Lady – after a tearful Theresa May announced her long-anticipated resignation yesterday with an emotional address outside No.With the vultures already circling, the Prime Minister finally admitted defeat after clinging to power through three stormy years. Stubborn to the last, she only broke down at the end of her speech in which she vowed to quit as Tory leader on June  to make way for a new PM by the end of July. Watched by devoted husband Philip and loyal senior aides, she said: “I will shortly leave the job that it has been the honour of my le to hold. “The second female Prime Minister, but certainly not the last. “I do so with no ill will, but with enormous and enduring gratitude to have had the opportunity to serve the country I love.” She will stand down as Tory leader on June  after a state visit by US president Donald Trump.    She will then remain as caretaker PM until her successor is elected by the end of July, when she will visit the Queen at Buckingham Palace and formally resign. Power-hungry Tory leadership rivals immediately began jostling to take over yesterday, led by frontrunner Boris Johnson.The former Foreign Secretary prompted accusations of hypocrisy after urging colleagues to “come together” to deliver Brexit – after spending months undermining Mrs May’s own strategy.He unleashed further fury by stressing he would back a damaging No Deal departure from the EU to ensure the UK leaves by the end of October.    Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, the favourite among MPs, waited barely three hours before announcing his own run for the top job.Jeremy Corbyn told the Mirror that whoever takes over must hold an election to “let the people decide our country’s future”.Mrs May’s announcement came after a final showdown at No  with Tory backbench chief Sir Graham Brady, who was prepared to trigger another no-confidence vote in her leadershipshe refused to resign. Her fate was sealed after her new Brexit plans earlier this week infuriated Tory backbenchers and many of her own Cabinet. Ahead of her statement, she rang her constituency chairman in Maidenhead, Berks, to tell him she was leaving No – but that she would not be standing down as an MP. Instead, she will decide what to do at the time of the next general election.    Mrs May stepped out through the black front door of No just after am yesterday to admit her Brexit plans had finally hit the wall. She wore a Peter Blake skirt suit in deep orange, a colour that represents change. Around her neck was a chunky silver-and-Perspex necklace, another of her trademark don’t-mess-with-me accessories, the size of which has increased with the scale of the mess she has faced in recent years. She said: “It is and will always remain a matter of deep regret to me that I have not been able to deliver Brexit. “I have done everything I can to convince MPs to back that deal. Sadly, I have not been able to do so. I tried three times. “I believe it was right to persevere, even where the odds against success seemed high.  “But it is now clear to me that it is in the best interests of the country for a new Prime Minister to lead that effort.” Mrs May quoted her late constituent Sir Nicholas Winton, the Kindertransport hero who rescued hundreds of children from the Nazis, urging Tory MPs to compromise over Brexit. She recalled: “He said, ‘Never forget that compromise is not a dirty word. Le depends on compromise.’ He was right’.” But she prompted a furious response from his daughter, Barbara Winton, who said: “Sadly, such admiration has not led to following in his footsteps in relation to today’s child refugees.” Mrs May’s claim that the inquiry into the Grenfell fire tragedy, in which  people died, was a proud legacy of her time in office was branded “disgraceful” by the Fire Brigades Union. Union chief Matt Wrack said: “Many of the underlying issues at Grenfell were due to unsafe conditions that had been allowed to fester under Tory governments and a council for which Theresa May bears ultimate responsibility.”  Her defeated, emotion-racked statement was in stark contrast to her first speech outside No when she became PM on July ,  and optimistically pledged to tackle the “burning injustices” she identied. But having failed to break the Commons Brexit deadlock, she finally agreed to leave. After a sobbing Mrs May walked back through the door of No  she was met with a round of applause by Downing Street staff. Tory party chiefs announced the leadership contest would begin on Monday June  to allow MPs time to whittle down the crowded field of up to  candidates by the end of the month. The heavily eurosceptic Tory membership would pick their leader after hustings around the country.  In previous contests this has been from the last two, but sources suggested the final shortlist could be longer to make sure Mr Johnson gets through. Party HQ wants a new leader to take over before the Commons rises for the summer, expected to be around July , to give time to bed down. Home Secretary Sajd Javid, Environment secretary Michael Gove and hardline Brexiteer Dominic Raab are all expected to stand, while even Sir Graham, who dealt the fatal blow to Mrs May’s leadership, stood down from his party role to consider standing. Mr Hunt said: “Now we need to put aide Brexit dferences and unite the party and country”. But former Foreign Secretary Mr Johnson deepened the Tory schism on Europe by ruling out another extension of Brexit beyond Octoberpicked for the top job.  It would give him a hard deadline of just three months to renegotiate a deal - or face the economic and political turmoil of leaving without one. At an economic conference in Switzerland, where he banned his speech being recorded, he said: “We will leave the EU on October , deal or no deal... “The way to get a good deal is to prepare for a no deal. To get things done you need to be prepared to walk away.” EU chiefs poured immediate scorn on Mr Johnson’s plans to try to reopen negotiations. “We would be really stupidwe had refused the reasonable negotiators and now suddenly reopen the door to Boris,” said one Brussels insider. Another denied that leaving No Deal on the table would force them to reopen talks. “No Deal has never impressed the EU. It is one of the [hard Brexiteer] myths to think it gives the UK leverage,” they said. The move accelerated the ‘Stop Boris’ campaign of anxious One Nation Tories who fear Mr Johnson could unleash chaos with his Brexit plans and drag the party further to the right. Defence minister Tobias Ellwood said: “If the Brexit experience to date has taught us anything, it’s to avoid making promises and drawing red lines you may later regret or cannot honour.”  Former Tory MP Nick Boles said: “I have many friends in the Tory Party but I’m afraid the party has nothing to offer the country now.  “A new leader will not end the ision, break the grip of ideology or be more in touch with people’s everyday concerns. The country needs something new.” aposSave your tears for the real victims of Theresaaposs MayhemaposComment by Kevin MaguireDon’t cry for cruel Theresa when it’s her victims who deserve our tears. May, like Margaret Thatcher, weeps only for herself. The cracking voice was the sound of self-pity over the collapse of her disastrous Premiership. Mendacious May’s record shows little affection for the millions whose lives she made worse. So let’s grieve not for an incompetent Tory PM but for the record number of hungry families forced to rely on foodbacks to eat.The struggling pushed below the breadline by Universal Credit .The tens of thousands of extra children abandoned in poverty, their lives blighted from birth. The pupils in schools and colleges begging parents to buy toilet rolls and clean classrooms. The sick who are hurting on longer NHS waiting lists or marooned in corridors on hospital trolleys. The burgled or kned denied justice after she sacked , police officers. The nurses, teachers, firefighters, council workers and civil servants whose incomes she squeezed. And all the workers whose wages are down more than a tenner on a decade ago. Let’s cry not for her but casualties of the le-sapping Tory austerity Mayhem.Tell us what you think: yourvoice@mirror

title: voice mirror its now time
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Its now time to go... to the pollsThere is no reason to believe the next Tory leader will be any more compassionate or useful than the last so its time for an electionShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAY NewsopinionOut with the old and in with the new should be the theme now that Theresa May has gone and the Tories are in tatters "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAll political careers inevitably end in failure but few have ended as miserably as that of Theresa May. She leaves after three years in No with the unwelcome distinction of having achieved almost nothing of any substance. Mrs May came to office with noble intentions, promising a fairer country and to end the burning injustices. In what became a pattern with her premiership, the words were never matched by deeds. She bequeaths a dismal domestic legacy of more than four million children in poverty, a record number of people using foodbanks and crumbling public services. There was no attempt to grapple with two of the biggest and most pressing challenges of our time, climate change and social care.    Judged on this alone, Mrs May would have ranked as one of the least accomplished PMs. But it is her failure on Brexit which will cement her place as one of the worst premiers. She ran for PM fully knowing delivering on the referendum would dominate her term. This was an act of hubris by someone whose temperament, management style and skill set have proven woefully insufficient. Her time in office will be remembered for its record number of ministerial resignations and the worst Commons defeat inflicted on a PM. Some will have sympathy for a PM who wept as she announced her departure. They should remember Mrs May shed no tears for the victims of the Windrush deportation scandal nor for those who have been left starving because of Universal Credit. While public services struggle and thousands of steelworkers face an uncertain future, the Tories will spend the next two months indulging in yet another leadership contest. There is no reason to believe the next leader will be any more successful than the last. Who takes over the reins of power should not be in the hands of Conservative MPs and a few thousands party members. If the next leader wants a mandate to govern they should call a general election.

title: first picture tragic boy 9
story: NewsFirst picture of tragic boy, , who died after locker fell on him at school clubMessages of condolences have been paid to grief-stricken parents Natalie and Eddie Lati following the tragic death of son Leo, who had been attending a swimming club at Great Baddow High School in Chelmsford, EssexShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsLeo Lati was killed in a tragic incident at school"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the first picture of a tragic youngster who died after a locker fell on him at an after-school club. Leo Lati, nine, had been swimming at Great Baddow High School in Chelmsford, Essex, on Thursday evening when a locker in the changing rooms fell on him. It is understood the youngster - who was not a pupil at the school - had climbed on it before falling off and becoming trapped underneath, police said. He suffered serious injuries and was treated at the scene before being rushed in an ambulance to a hospital six miles away.However, sadly little Leo succumbed to his injuries and died .Messages of condolences have been paid to grief-stricken parents Natalie and Eddie, as well as Leoaposs younger brother.    In a statement Maria Rumsey, Headteacher at St Michael’s Primary School, said: All the staff, parents, governors and pupils from St Michael’s school are shocked and immensely saddened to hear of the tragic death of our Year  pupil, Leo Lati. He will be greatly missed by all. We wish to extend our thoughts and condolences to all of Leo’s family and friends at this saddest of times. Leo was a sparkle in our school. His face lit up the classroom and his mischievous blue eyes made us all smile. He was an avid scientist, who only on Wednesday, was in his element hunting for bugs on the school field. Leo was always keen to share his model-building and wowed the class when he brought in the finished masterpieces! He had a wide circle of friends in the year group, all of whom will miss him greatly. We are supporting all of our children and staff today as we try to come to terms with this sad loss. We are a strong and close community and will ensure that everybody is given the necessary help. In order to do this, we would ask that you respect the privacy of the family and school community at this time. Essex Police and the governmentaposs Health and Safety Executive are investigating the circumstances behind his tragic death which has left the community in shock. Great Baddow High School, a specialist sports and science college for around  students aged between  and , did not wish to comment. It was closed to students on Friday, except for those taking GCSE and A-Level exams. It has a reputation for sport both locally and at a national level and has an indoor swimming pool on site which is regularly hired out for private lessons.  Sue Shaw runs a weekly class on a Thursday night and was forced to cancel Thursday nightaposs lesson due to the incident. She said: I just arrived and saw what was going on so I had to cancel my swimming lesson. It wasnapost very nice. Sue insisted the youngster was not a member of her swim school and said: I donapost want to comment further.She also posted an update to her followers on Facebook , which read: FAO Baddow swimmers, swimming is cancelled tonight.On Friday morning, a child was seen at the gates of the school handing over flowers to a member of staff. Meanwhile, a spokesperson for Essex Police said: The nine-year-old boy was believed to have fallen from a locker and become trapped underneath it. He was taken to hospital, where he sadly died.  We are liaising with the Health and Safety Executive. The child was not a pupil at the school and had been there with family members at an after school club. Witnesses said they heard numerous ambulances rushing to the scene. An air ambulance was also spotted landing nearby. An ambulance trust spokesman said: “We were called to reports that a child had been seriously injured at the Baddow School swimming pool in Chelmsford around . on Thursday evening. We treated the child at the scene and transported him to Broomfield Hospital. Essex and Herts Air Ambulance attended but the boy was taken to hospital by road.  Residents living near the school have also spoken of their shock. Keith and Jackie Knaggaposs four children went to the school. Keith said: I only found out this morning when I went over to the newsagents, I couldn’t work out why the kids weren’t in school. We saw the air ambulance, it was right over the house. It was rattling the windows and I couldn’t understand why it was so low. Jackie added: We heard the ambulance and the helicopter but we didn’t realise it was for the little boy. All I can say is that I’m really shocked and upset, especially for the parents.

title: head bgts flakefleet primary school
story: NewsHead of BGTs Flakefleet Primary School aims to make pupils dreams a realityEXCLUSIVE: Pupils became a golden buzzer act on the ITV show — and it may be down to their head David McPartlin, , who brings joy to the classroomShareCommentsByJulie McCaffrey:,  MAY NewsDave McPartlin on the trolley with pupilsAngelica Wells, Lewis Wells, Chloe Fenney-Schofield, Dave, Jamie Hagarth, Lewis Geddes and Mia McLeish "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe head teacher is folded into a shopping trolley and giggling kids are pushing him, full pelt, down the corridor. He’s ­laughing even louder than they are.Excitement levels at Flakefleet Primary School are through the roof ever since David Walliams ’ golden buzzer shot them straight to Monday’s live semi final of Britain’s Got Talent.The pupils made the funnyman judge cry with happy tears with their charmingly hilarious performance of Queen’s Don’t Stop Me Now. The choir sang at the top of their lungs, as a junior version of the Spice Girls danced and a zorbing bunny rolled by. A tiny superhero on a racing car trolley zoomed across the stage, and an even smaller version of Dec popped up from a wheelie bin.    Their joyous audition has racked up . million views on YouTube. How much did it all cost  “Nothing,” shrugs head teacher Mr McPartlin. He’s called Dave, but it seems wrong to call him anything other than Mr McPartlin just like his pupils do. “The kids glued, stapled and painted all the costumes with a lot of help from teachers and parents. “Tesco lent us a trolley, although Miss Smith lost her pound deposit. Even the coach company that took us to Manchester gave mates’ rates.” The -year-old head insists the BGT success is down to the kids. But he’s the man who put laughter on the curriculum at a school, seven miles north of Blackpool where % of children receive free school meals. “We are proudly working class,” says Mr McPartlin, originally from Hartlepool. “Just like my parents taught me, you can achieve anything you set your mind to.”    Flakefleet’s motto is “Dare to dream” and Mr McPartlin wants them to dream big. Last year, a plan to ­celebrate the royal wedding by singing songs in a church grew arms and legs. He says: “We ended up with a horse-drawn carriage carrying our own version of Harry and Meghan through streets adorned with bunting. “Then one boy said we should’ve had a helicopter, so we held a raffle and hired one. We want to teach our kids anything’s possible.” Seven-year-old Scott Wood said he wanted to be a photographer, so they lent him cameras and helped him land his first paid gig as a wedding photographer. He is still in pay talks. As he takes me on a proud tour of the open plan school, Mr McPartlin fizzes with infectious charisma. Walking from one side of the building, he is bombarded by class-loads of children who run up for a group hug. “I fell in love with this school the moment I first came three years ago,” he says. “It hit me like a double decker bus. Everyone was so welcoming, smiley, special.” No one’s giving anything away about their next performance. A girl in a reception class is slathering a balloon with papier-mâché but hides the prop when we approach.  Birthday parties have been missed, parents have spent evenings bent over sewing machines, and one family ­rearranged their holiday. Teacher Hayley Wild brought in her one-year-old son Ollie while she supervised a weekend of rehearsals for the  choir kids. She’s seen a surge in confidence since their BGT audition. Mrs Wild says: “The first time we asked who wanted to do solos, the kids squirmed and looked to their feet. This time they all stepped forward. “Sometimes, when we’ve listened to them, we’ve thought ‘where did that voice come from ’. “There’s one boy who makes me cry every time he sings. I’m filling up thinking about it.” In the gym hall, tape maps the size of the stage at London’s Hammersmith Apollo, where the live semi-final will take place. The audition costumes are stored, some still full of gold ticker tape, and the zorb’s puncture has been mended with an Elastoplast. New costumes and semi final props are in production. Teaching assistant Christine Smith is sewing pink ribbon on to what looks like an angel dress. She says: “Everyone’s mucked in. It’s amazing what you can do with tin foil and a glue gun.” Simon Cowell’s company offered Flakefleet the ­expertise of their stage managers and the pick of props. But that’s not how things are done here. Mr McPartlin, who has a fiancee and three children, says: “Half the fun is getting all the kids involved in making everything.    “I’ll never forget looking at the immaculate dancers in crystal-covered costumes backstage at BGT, then at my lovely kids in painted ­cardboard. I felt so proud.” Five-year-old Hugo Blundell, who was little Dec in the audition and has a nickname of Bin Boy, is peering into the wheelie bin and says he can’t wait to get back in. He says: “It was dark but I’d a torch so checked for cobwebs.” Ten-year-old Jaimie McGrath’s eyes widen as she remembers dancing in a shower of golden buzzer ticker tape. “It was the best feeling in my whole le. I will always remember it even when I’m really old, like, thirty.” Lewis Geddes, , appeared as mini Ant and Lewis Wells, , who was supersonic man, laugh as they recall their mums “crying their eyes out”. In the library the books are all out in the David Walliams section. The most requested song on the school radio station is Don’t Stop Me Now. Big dreams can sometimes be big letdowns. But Mr McPartlin has also prepared his pupils for harsh realities.    If they don’t make it though to the final, how will they cheer up the kids  “We won’t need to,” he says. “We’re teaching the kids to be resilient. “We tell them they’ll have setbacks, but the important thing is to keep going.” That’s why he applied for Britain’s Got Talent, even though some staff thought he’d lost the plot. “We’d have been happy just with applause. The kids won’t remember their SATs, but they’ll remember this. “One of the parents said, ‘knowing the Flakefleet kids,they put their minds to it they could probably win the World Cup’.”

title: mums should avoid eating crisps
story: NewsMums-to-be should avoid eating crisps to protect their unborn childScientists found that omega- fat in crisp fat affects growth and development of rats unborn babies and causes uterus contractionsShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  MAY NewsMunching on crisps while youre expecting may not be a good idea, according to new research "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEating too many crisps during pregnancy could have a negative effect on the development of the baby, a study suggests. Crisps contain an omega- fat called linoleic acid that was previously thought to have health benefits such as lowering blood cholesterol. But researchers found that feeding rats with three times the recommended daily intake of linoleic acid decreased hormones that regulate the growth and development of their unborn babies. It also affected their liverand increased proteins that cause contractions in the uterus, according to the findings published in The Journal of Physiology.    Up until recently, people were encouraged to consume omega- fats because it was thought to help to reduce blood cholesterol. And vegetable oil, which also contains linoleic acid, was marketed as a healthy and cheaper alternative to using animal fats in cooking. Study senior author Dr Deanne Skelly, of Grfith University, said: “It is important for pregnant women to consider their diet, and our research is yet another example that potentially consuming too much of a certain type of nutrient can have a negative impact on the growing baby.” The research team at Grfith University in Queensland, Australia, fed rats for  weeks on a diet with high linoelic acid and mated them.    They then investigated the effects of the diet on their pregnancy and the development of their offspring. The team also found rat mothers who ate a high linoleic acid diet had a reduced number of male babies. It is not known whether the same effects would be seen in humans or what amounts of linoleic acid would be harmful.
